title: Accessing predicted values
text: FishLife R package estimating evolutionary trade-offs among traits >34,000 described fishes. also applies phylogenetic trait imputation, .e., used predict reposit predicted life-history parameters fishes, imputed values informed life-history correlations similarities among related species. package comes three databases pre-run results: database results described Thorson et al. (2023), introducing phylogenetic structural equation models combining phylogenetic comparative methods describe trade-offs among larger set life-history, morphometric, behavioral, trophic, reproductive traits; database results described Thorson (2020), applying phylogenetic factor analysis original database well RAM Legacy database records stock-recruit relationships estimate full life-cycle model species; original database results described Thorson Munch Cope Gao (2017), introducing phylogenetic factor analysis using records size, growth, maturity, mortality parameters FishBase downloaded 2016. vignete, show access output various models.

title: Accessing predicted values
text: graphical user interface (GUI) available online. However, updated recently, shows results Thorson Munch Cope Gao (2017).
code: # Install and load package # devtools::install_github("james-thorson/FishLife", dep=TRUE) library( FishLife )

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Starting Thorson et al. (2023), FishLife uses ape class phylo represent relatedness among taxa. several benefits: facilitates collaboration evolutionary ecological researchers fishes; represents relatedness based evolutionary distance, rather simply approximating relatedness based taxonomy; allows FishLife use well-maintained dependencies input(read, subset, merge) output (plot tabulate) results. However, also results changes results accessed. Although provide function (FishLife::FishBase_and_Morphometrics,"phylo4d"), find slow useful. Therefore, instead recommend searching taxon name manually. demonstrate red snapper:
code: edge_names = c( FishBase_and_Morphometrics$tree$tip.label,                 FishBase_and_Morphometrics$tree$node.label[-1] ) # Removing root                  # which_g = match( "Lutjanus campechanus", edge_names ) Table2023 = cbind(    Mean = FishBase_and_Morphometrics$beta_gv[which_g,],   SE = sqrt(diag(FishBase_and_Morphometrics$Cov_gvv[which_g,,])) ) knitr::kable( Table2023, digits=3)

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Thorson (2020) analysis sought maintain customized code accessing plotting results. demonstrate red snapper, within FishBase database used train model predictions relatively precise.  show updated values predictive mean standard errors… Predict[[1]]$Mean_pred provides mean values, Predict[[1]]$Cov_pred provides predictive covariance life-history parameters. Traits log-space except Temperature, generation time G intrinsict growth rate r. analyst wants back-transform trait reported log-space, thought given whether analyst wants use predictive median predictive mean. predictive median calculated expnoentiating log-space values, predictive mean requires bias-correction (perhaps based lognormal assumption using predictive variance). Finally generation time G intrinsict growth rate r calculated based nonlinear transformation traits using Euler-Lotka formula, therefore report mean either log-space natural space, obtained sampling constituent traits, calculating values sample, computing mean calculations. Given procedure, exponentiating ln_G typically equal G holds ln_r r.
code: # Get basic plot for Lutjanus campechanus Taxa = Search_species( Genus = "Lutjanus",                        Species = "campechanus")$match_taxonomy Predict = Plot_taxa( Taxa,                       mfrow=c(3,2) ) #>      [,1]           [,2]          #> [1,] "K"            "M"           #> [2,] "Winfinity"    "Loo"         #> [3,] "tmax"         "tm"          #> [4,] "Lm"           "Temperature" #> [5,] "ln_margsd"    "rho"         #> [6,] "logitbound_h" "ln_r"

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Next demonstrate cortez rockfish, within FishBase database used train model, predictions relatively based information related species within genus Sebastes.
code: # Get basic plot for Sebastes cortezi Taxa = Search_species( Genus = "Sebastes",                        Species = "cortezi")$match_taxonomy Predict = Plot_taxa( Taxa,                       mfrow=c(3,2) ) #>      [,1]           [,2]          #> [1,] "K"            "M"           #> [2,] "Winfinity"    "Loo"         #> [3,] "tmax"         "tm"          #> [4,] "Lm"           "Temperature" #> [5,] "ln_margsd"    "rho"         #> [6,] "logitbound_h" "ln_r"

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Third, demonstrate predictions family Scombridae, show predictions available higher-level taxonomies.
code: # Get basic plot for Family Scombridae  Plot_taxa( Search_species(Family="Scombridae")$match_taxonomy, mfrow=c(3,2) ) #>      [,1]           [,2]          #> [1,] "K"            "M"           #> [2,] "Winfinity"    "Loo"         #> [3,] "tmax"         "tm"          #> [4,] "Lm"           "Temperature" #> [5,] "ln_margsd"    "rho"         #> [6,] "logitbound_h" "ln_r"

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Fourth, compare predictions two species, brown rainbow trout.
code: # Compare two species Taxa = c( Search_species(Genus="Oncorhynchus",Species="mykiss",add_ancestors=FALSE)$match_taxonomy,   Search_species(Genus="Salmo",Species="Trutta",add_ancestors=FALSE)$match_taxonomy ) Plot_taxa( Taxa, mfrow=c(3,2) ) #>      [,1]           [,2]          #> [1,] "K"            "M"           #> [2,] "Winfinity"    "Loo"         #> [3,] "tmax"         "tm"          #> [4,] "Lm"           "Temperature" #> [5,] "ln_margsd"    "rho"         #> [6,] "logitbound_h" "ln_r"

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Results Thorson et al. (2017) accessed similarly, indicating earlier database:  can access mean predicted values:
code: # Get basic plot for Lutjanus campechanus Taxa = Search_species( Genus = "Lutjanus",                        Species="campechanus",                        Database = FishBase )$match_taxonomy params = matrix( c( "Loo", "K", "Winfinity", "tmax",                      "tm", "M", "Lm", "Temperature"), ncol=2 ) Predict = Plot_taxa( Taxa,                       mfrow=c(2,2),                      Database = FishBase,                      params = params ) #>      [,1]        [,2]          #> [1,] "Loo"       "tm"          #> [2,] "K"         "M"           #> [3,] "Winfinity" "Lm"          #> [4,] "tmax"      "Temperature"

title: Accessing predicted values
text: Finally, given ongoing effort, natural wonder whether output consistent across database compilations, statistical assumptions, associated model specification. therefore compare results red snapper

title: Archetypes
text: show replicate extract archetypes estimated Thorson et al. 2023. first load packages data: Next re-run archetype analysis plot resulting simplex archetypes  interested, can pull values individual species based Latin binomial. show examples:  Finally, can plot distribution predicted traits species, along predicted mean archetype:
code: # Load packages and data library(archetypes) library(FishLife) data(FishBase_and_Morphometrics)  # Set seed so that archetypes are labeled the same way when replicating suppressWarnings(RNGversion("3.5.0")) set.seed(1986) # Load results beta_iv = FishBase_and_Morphometrics$beta_gv[ FishBase_and_Morphometrics$g_i, ] a <- archetypes(beta_iv, 3, verbose = TRUE) #> 1: rss = 0.00844337, improvement = 0.00939731 #> 2: rss = 0.00789766, improvement = 0.00054571 #> 3: rss = 0.00779479, improvement = 0.00010287 #> 4: rss = 0.00778014, improvement = 0.00001465 #> 5: rss = 0.00777922, improvement = 0.00000092 #> 6: rss = 0.00777984, improvement = -0.00000062  # Labels Labels = c("Equil.","Oppor.","Per.")[c(1,3,2)] Col_names = colnames(FishBase_and_Morphometrics$Y_ij)   Col_names = gsub("habitat", "H: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("body_shape", "BS: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("feeding_mode", "FM: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("spawning_type", "ST: ", Col_names )  # Col function mycol = function(x,alpha){   y = col2rgb(x)   rgb( y[1,1]/255, y[2,1]/255, y[3,1]/255, alpha=alpha) }  # Plot by taxa Z_ik = FishBase_and_Morphometrics$Z_ik simplex = simplexplot(a, show_points=FALSE, labels=Labels) #, projection=atypes_projection) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Gobiidae"), ], col=mycol("brown",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Percidae"), ], col=mycol("orange",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Salmonidae"), ], col=mycol("red",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Scorpaenidae"), ], col=mycol("grey",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Clupeidae"), ], col=mycol("green",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Class=="Elasmobranchii"), ], col=mycol("black",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Poeciliidae"), ], col=mycol("blue",0.5), pch=20 ) points( simplex$proj_h[which(Z_ik$Family=="Atherinidae"), ], col=mycol("purple",0.5), pch=20 ) legend( "topleft", bty="n", ncol=2, legend=c("Gobiidae","Salmonidae","Poeciliidae",         "Atherinidae","Percidae","Scorpaenidae","Clupeidae","Elasmobranchii"),         fill=c("brown","red","blue","purple","orange","grey","green","black")) # Pull out examples Z_ik = FishBase_and_Morphometrics$Z_ik species_to_plot = data.frame(   c("Gadus_macrocephalus", "Hippoglossus_stenolepis", "Sebastes_alutus", "Thaleichthys_pacificus",      "Oncorhynchus_tshawytscha", "Somniosus_pacificus", "Mallotus_villosus", "Boreogadus_saida",      "Bothrocara_brunneum", "Tarletonbeania_taylori", "Gambusia_affinis", "Callogobius_sclateri",      "Acanthurus_xanthopterus", "Eviota_jewettae"),   c( "Pacific cod", "Halibut", "Paciric Ocean perch", "Eulachon", "Chinook", "Sleeper shark",      "Capelin", "Arctic cod", "twoline eelpout", "North Pacific lanternfish",      "Western mosquitofish", "Pacific goby", "Yellowfin surgeonfish", "Jewett's dwarfgoby") ) species_to_plot$color = rainbow(nrow(species_to_plot)) # Plot by taxa simplex = simplexplot(a, show_points=FALSE, labels=Labels) for( r in seq_len(nrow(species_to_plot)) ){   which_row = which(paste0(Z_ik$Genus,"_",Z_ik$Species)==species_to_plot[r,1])   text( x=simplex$proj_h[which_row,1], y=simplex$proj_h[which_row,2],         col=species_to_plot[r,3], labels=letters[r] ) } legend( "topleft", bty="n", ncol=2, legend=species_to_plot[,2], fill=species_to_plot[,3]) Col_names = colnames(FishBase_and_Morphometrics$beta_gv)   Col_names = gsub("habitat", "H: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("body_shape", "BS: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("feeding_mode", "FM: ", Col_names )   Col_names = gsub("spawning_type", "ST: ", Col_names ) dims = c(6,6) par( mfrow=dims, mgp=c(2,0.5,0), mar=c(1,1,2,0), tck=-0.02 ) for( cI in 1:ncol(FishBase_and_Morphometrics$beta_gv) ){   hist( FishBase_and_Morphometrics$beta_gv[,cI],         main=Col_names[cI], xlab="", ylab="", yaxt="n" )   abline( v=parameters(a)[,cI], col=viridisLite::viridis(3), lwd=3 ) }

text: James Thorson. Author, maintainer.

text: Thorson J (2023). FishLife: Predict Life History Parameters Fish. R package version 3.1.0, https://james-thorson-noaa.github.io/FishLife/, http://github.com/James-Thorson-NOAA/FishLife.
code: @Manual{,   title = {FishLife: Predict Life History Parameters For Any Fish},   author = {James Thorson},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 3.1.0, https://james-thorson-noaa.github.io/FishLife/},   url = {http://github.com/James-Thorson-NOAA/FishLife}, }

what: Predict Life History Parameters For Any Fish
title: Predict Life History Parameters For Any Fish
text: FishLife collaborative international project aims : Compile life-history traits (demographic parameters well behavioral, reproductive, morphological, trophic traits) Estimate trade-offs among traits imputing missing values; Distribute imputed trait-values (standard errors) use fisheries science management. FishLife R-package includes results three prior analyses: database results described Thorson et al. (2023), introducing phylogenetic structural equation models combining phylogenetic comparative methods describe trade-offs among larger set life-history, morphometric, behavioral, trophic, reproductive traits; database results described Thorson (2020), applying phylogenetic factor analysis original database well RAM Legacy database records stock-recruit relationships estimate full life-cycle model species; original database results described Thorson Munch Cope Gao (2017), introducing phylogenetic factor analysis using records size, growth, maturity, mortality parameters FishBase downloaded 2016. three analyses, R-package FishLife includes compiled database trait measurements (aim-1), estimated covariance among traits (aim-2), imputed trait values (aim-3). See package vignettes details.

what: Calculate ratio of two modeled traits — Calculate_ratio
title: Calculate ratio of two modeled traits — Calculate_ratio
text: Calculate_ratio projects covariance among traits onto single difference (interpreted ratio log-scaled traits)

title: Calculate ratio of two modeled traits — Calculate_ratio
code: Calculate_ratio(   params = c("K", "M"),   Database = FishLife::FishBase_and_RAM,   Cov_gjj = Database$Cov_gvv,   Mean_gj = Database$beta_gv,   ParentChild_gz = Database$ParentChild_gz )

title: Calculate ratio of two modeled traits — Calculate_ratio
text: params Parameter names use calculation Cov_gjj Array estimated covariance taxonomic group g trait j Mean_gj Matrix Empirical Bayes predictions traits taxonomic group ParentChild_gz Matrix representing taxonomic tree analyzed data

title: Calculate ratio of two modeled traits — Calculate_ratio
text: Matrix exponentiated-differences (ratios) log-standard deviations projection median median difference taxonomic group N_obsfactors log-standard deviation difference taxonomic group

what: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
title: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
text: Fit_model estimates parameters predicts values multivariate random-walk model fish traits

title: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
code: Fit_model(   text = NULL,   Database = FishLife::FishBase_and_RAM,   tree = Database$tree,   Y_ij = Database$Y_ij,   Z_ik = Database$Z_ik,   Use_REML = TRUE,   N_factors = 0,   N_obsfactors = 0,   min_replicate_measurements = 0,   SR_obs = Database$SR_obs,   StockData = Database$StockData,   group_j = 1:ncol(Y_ij) - 1,   Version = "Taxon_v3_0_0",   TmbDir = system.file("executables", package = "FishLife"),   RunDir = tempfile(pattern = "run_", tmpdir = tempdir(), fileext = "/"),   verbose = FALSE,   debug_mode = FALSE,   j_SR = ncol(Y_ij) - 3:1,   additional_variance = c(0, 0),   SD_b_stock = 10,   b_type = 0,   Turn_off_taxonomy = FALSE,   Pen_lowvar_lnRhat = 1,   lowerbound_MLSPS = 1,   Use_RAM_Mvalue_TF = TRUE,   rho_space = "natural",   n_sims = 1000,   n_batches = NULL,   include_r = TRUE,   PredTF_stock = NULL,   extract_covariance = FALSE,   run_model = TRUE,   multinomial_for_factors = FALSE,   Params = "Generate",   Random = "Generate",   Map = "Generate",   add_predictive = FALSE,   ... )

title: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
text: text structural equation model structure, passed either specifyModel parsed control set path coefficients variance-covariance parameters Database Whether use results adult stock-recruit parameters, Database="FishBase_and_RAM", just adult parameters, Database="FishBase" tree phylogenetic structure, using class .phylo.  tree=NULL argument Z_ik instead converted tree using  ape::.phylo( ~Class/Order/Family/Genus/GenusSpecies, ... ) convert tree Y_ij data frame trait values (perhaps log-scaled) rows records, tagged-columns traits Z_ik data frame taxonomic classification row Y_ij Use_REML OPTIONAL boolean whether use maximum marginal likelihood restricted maximum likelihood (termed "REML") N_factors Number factors decomposition covariance random-walk along evolutionary tree (0 means diagonal unequal covariance; negative sum factor decomposition diagonal--unequal covariance) N_obsfactors Number factors decomposotion observation covariance (format N_obsfactors) min_replicate_measurements specified threshold number measurements given continuous traits, continuous trait fewer replicated measurements least one taxon  measurement variance fixed arbitrarily low value, estimated traits forced approach unreplicated measurements SR_obs Stock-recruit records RAM Legacy stock-recruit database StockData Auxiliary information every stock stock-recruit information Version TMB version number TmbDir Directory containing pre-compiled TMB script RunDir Directory use compiling running TMB script (different avoid problems read-write restrictions) verbose Boolean whether print diagnostics terminal run_model Boolean indicating whether run model just return built TMB object Params optional list parameter estimates use starting values (Default Params="Generate" starts random values) ... paramers passed fit_tmb Process_cov Whether process-error covariance equal differs multiplicatively different taxonomic levels (Options:  "Equal" "Unequal")

title: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
text: Tagged list containing objects FishLife run (first 9 slots constitute list 'Estimate_database' archiving results) tree phylogenetic tree used analysis, whether inputted generated taxonomy based Z_ik SEM_model phylogenetic tree used analysis, whether inputted generated taxonomy based Z_ik N_factors Number factors used evolution life-history model N_obsfactors Number factors used measurent-error life-history model Use_REML Boolean, whether REML used model Cov_gjj Covariance among traits every taxon tree ParentChild_gz Record taxonomic tree ParHat Parameter estimates predictions g_i Associates every observation level taxonomic tree Y_ij Raw data Z_ik Taxonomy datum Obj built TMB object Opt Output optimization Report tagged list report-file TMB ParHat_SE Estimated/predicted standard errors fixed/random effects

title: Fit and predict fish traits — Fit_model
code: if (FALSE) { # Load data set library(FishLife)  # Simulate data tree = ape::rtree(n=100) xfit = x = 1 + 0.3 * phylolm::rTrait(n = 1, phy=tree) yfit = y = 2 + 1*x + 0.3 * phylolm::rTrait(n = 1, phy=tree) drop_x = sample( 1:ape::Ntip(tree), replace=FALSE, size=round(ape::Ntip(tree)*0.3) ) xfit[drop_x] = NA drop_y = sample( 1:ape::Ntip(tree), replace=FALSE, size=round(ape::Ntip(tree)*0.3) ) yfit[drop_y] = NA  # Fit model Fit = Fit_model(   text = "x -> y, p",   Database = NULL,   Use_REML = FALSE,   Y_ij = data.frame( x=xfit, y=yfit ),   tree = tree,   min_replicate_measurements = Inf )  # S3-defaults print(Fit) coef(Fit)  # Convet and plot using sem mysem = as(Fit,"sem") sem::pathDiagram( model = mysem,                   style = "traditional",                   edge.labels = "values" ) myplot = semPlot::semPlotModel( as(Fit,"sem") ) semPlot::semPaths( myplot,                    nodeLabels = myplot@Vars$name )  # Convert and plot using phylobase / phylosignal library(phylobase) plot( as(Fit,"phylo4d") ) }

title: Optimize a TMB model — fit_tmb
text: fit_tmb runs TMB model generates standard diagnostics

title: Optimize a TMB model — fit_tmb
code: fit_tmb(   obj,   fn = obj$fn,   gr = obj$gr,   startpar = NULL,   lower = -Inf,   upper = Inf,   getsd = TRUE,   control = list(eval.max = 10000, iter.max = 10000, trace = 1),   bias.correct = FALSE,   bias.correct.control = list(sd = FALSE, split = NULL, nsplit = NULL, vars_to_correct =     NULL),   savedir = NULL,   loopnum = 2,   newtonsteps = 0,   n = Inf,   getReportCovariance = FALSE,   getJointPrecision = FALSE,   getHessian = FALSE,   quiet = FALSE,   start_time_elapsed = as.difftime("0:0:0"),   ... )

title: Optimize a TMB model — fit_tmb
text: obj compiled TMB object startpar Starting values fixed effects (default NULL uses obj$par) lower, upper vectors lower upper bounds, replicated long     start.  unspecified, parameters assumed     unconstrained. getsd Boolean indicating whether run standard error calculation; see sdreport details control list control parameters. details see nlminb bias.correct Boolean indicating whether epsilon bias-correction; see sdreport fit_tmbfor details bias.correct.control tagged list options epsilon bias-correction, vars_to_correct character-vector ADREPORT variables bias-corrected savedir directory save results (savedir=NULL, results saved) loopnum number times re-start optimization (loopnum=3 sometimes achieves lower final gradient loopnum=1) newtonsteps Integer specifying number extra newton steps take optimization (alternative loopnum). newtonstep requires calculating Hessian matrix therefore slow. well-behaved models, Newton step typically decrease maximum gradient loglikelihood respect fixed effect, therefore option can used achieve arbitrarily low final gradient given sufficient time well-behaved models.  However, option also perform strangely unexpected consequences poorly-behaved models, e.g., fixed effects upper lower bounds. n sample sizes (n!=Inf n used calculate BIC AICc) getReportCovariance Get full covariance matrix ADREPORTed variables? getJointPrecision Optional. Return full joint precision matrix random effects parameters? getHessian return Hessian usage later code quiet Boolean whether print additional messages results terminal start_time_elapsed much time elapsed prior calling fit_tmb, use, e.g., calling fit_tmb multiple times sequence, start_time_elapsed = opt_previous$time_for_run ... list settings pass sdreport

title: Optimize a TMB model — fit_tmb
text: standard output nlminb, except additional diagnostics timing info,         new slot containing output sdreport
